Question Text: Do you have accessibility information available for customers before they visit?
Helper Text: Examples: a dedicated accessibility page, accessibility guide, social story or visual narrative, information included across relevant pages, or clear pre-visit guidance.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: What's currently stopping you from sharing accessibility information?
Helper Text: Select all that apply
Response Options: Not sure what to include | Don't have time or resources | Concerned about accuracy | Don't think it's needed | Other

Question Text: Where would it be easiest to start sharing accessibility information?
Helper Text: Select one or more options
Response Options: Website | Social media | Booking confirmation emails | Printed materials | Google Business Profile | Other

Question Text: What types of accessibility information do you currently share?
Helper Text: Select all that apply. This might include physical access details, sensory environment, what to expect during a visit, transport and parking, or information about equipment and resources available such as sensory kits, sensory maps, or wheelchair hire.
Response Options: Physical access (entrances, parking, toilets) | Sensory environment (noise, lighting, crowds) | What to expect during a visit | Transport and parking | Equipment and resources available (sensory kits, sensory maps, wheelchair hire) | Contact information for accessibility questions | None of these

Question Text: How confident are you that this information is accurate and up to date?
Response Options: Very confident | Fairly confident | Not very confident | Not sure

Question Text: Would you like us to review a link to your accessibility information to help identify gaps and opportunities?
Helper Text: This review is indicative only and based on publicly available information. It does not verify accuracy or confirm compliance.
Response Options: Yes | No

Question Text: Paste the link where your accessibility information is shared
Helper Text: This review is indicative only and based on publicly available information. It does not verify accuracy or confirm compliance.
Response Options: Free text (URL)

Question Text: Can customers contact you in a variety of ways to ask accessibility questions before visiting?
Helper Text: Examples include phone, email, social media, contact forms, or booking enquiries.
Response Options: Yes | Limited options | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do staff know how to confidently respond to accessibility enquiries?
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you offer familiarisation visits or orientation sessions?
Helper Text:
Familiarisation visits allow people to visit your venue before their main visit to become comfortable with the environment, layout, staff, and what to expect. This is especially helpful for people with autism, anxiety, cognitive disabilities, or sensory sensitivities.

Familiarisation might include:
• Pre-visit tours at quieter times
• Virtual walkthroughs or video tours
• Social stories or visual guides
• Meeting key staff beforehand
• Exploring the space without pressure to participate

This can significantly reduce anxiety and improve the overall experience.
Response Options: Yes | On request | Considering it | No

Question Text: Do you provide information about accessible transport options to reach your venue?
Helper Text:
Transport information helps people plan their journey. This might include:

• Nearest accessible public transport stops
• Accessible parking locations
• Drop-off points and pick-up arrangements
• Walking distances from transport
• Taxi or ride-share drop-off information
• Accessible route maps

This information is particularly helpful when included in pre-visit communications or on your website.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Where is your accessibility information published?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. Understanding where your information lives helps identify whether customers can find it easily, and whether it's consistent across platforms.

Note: Accessibility information buried in FAQs or general information pages can be difficult for customers to find. A dedicated, clearly labelled accessibility page is easier to locate and signals that accessibility matters to your organisation.
Response Options: Dedicated accessibility page | Scattered across multiple pages | Within FAQs or general information | PDFs or downloadable documents | Third-party platforms (Google, booking sites) | Social media only | Other

Question Text: How easy is it to find your accessibility information from your homepage?
Helper Text: This measures findability, which is one of the most common real-world failures in accessibility information. Even well-written content has limited value if customers cannot locate it.
Response Options: One click | Two to three clicks | Hard to locate or requires searching | Not sure

Question Text: Is this information written primarily for customers or for compliance?
Helper Text:
Customer-focused information helps people make decisions and plan visits. Compliance-focused information often uses technical language and may not answer the questions customers actually have.

The most useful accessibility information does both: it meets obligations while genuinely helping people understand what to expect.
Response Options: Primarily for customers | Primarily for compliance | A mix of both | Not sure

Question Text: Does your physical access information include specific details that help customers plan?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. Decision-enabling information goes beyond general statements to include specifics that help people assess whether your venue works for them.

This might include:
• Measurements (door widths, gradients)
• Photos of entrances and toilets
• Step-free route descriptions
• Notes about limitations or constraints

General statements like 'we are accessible' are less useful than specific, honest details.
Response Options: Measurements (door widths, gradients) | Photos of entrances and toilets | Step-free route descriptions | Notes about limitations or constraints | None of these

Question Text: Does your 'what to expect' information describe the sensory and social environment?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. This type of information helps people prepare for their visit and reduces anxiety.

Useful details might include:
• Queuing and waiting expectations
• Noise levels at different times
• Lighting conditions and changes
• Crowd density at peak and quiet times
• Staff interactions and what to expect at key touchpoints

This is especially valuable for autistic visitors, people with anxiety, or those with sensory sensitivities.
Response Options: Queuing and waiting expectations | Noise levels at different times | Lighting conditions and changes | Crowd density at peak and quiet times | Staff interactions and what to expect | None of these
Condition: B1-F-2B includes What to expect during a visit

Question Text: When was your accessibility information last reviewed or updated?
Helper Text: Regular review helps ensure information stays accurate as your venue, services, or staff change. Outdated information can lead to poor experiences and erode trust.
Response Options: Within the last 6 months | 6 to 12 months ago | More than a year ago | Not sure

Question Text: Has your accessibility information been checked against any of these sources?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. Verification helps ensure accuracy and builds confidence that the information reflects reality.

If you haven't verified your information recently, this is an area to prioritise.
Response Options: A site inspection or walkthrough | Staff knowledge review | Customer feedback | An access consultant audit | Not checked

Question Text: How are accessibility enquiries handled when they come in?
Helper Text:
This explores whether accessibility questions receive consistent, confident responses.

Consistent handling helps customers feel confident their needs will be understood.
Response Options: Routed to trained staff who can answer confidently | Handled by whoever is available at the time | Sometimes missed, delayed, or answered inconsistently | Not sure

Question Text: Do customers have a way to ask accessibility questions without calling?
Helper Text:
Phone calls can be a barrier for some customers, including Deaf people, those with anxiety, or people who prefer written communication.

Alternative options might include email, contact forms, live chat, social media messaging, or text/SMS. The key is ensuring these channels are monitored and responded to reliably.
Response Options: Yes - multiple options | Yes - one alternative | No - phone only | Not sure

Question Text: Do you proactively invite accessibility questions?
Helper Text:
Proactive invitations signal that accessibility matters to your organisation and that questions are welcome.

This might include:
• A prompt on your website encouraging accessibility questions
• Text in booking confirmations inviting people to share requirements
• Staff trained to ask if there's anything they can help with

This removes the burden from customers to initiate the conversation.
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Have you tested whether your contact channels are accessible and usable for customers with disability?
Helper Text:
This includes things like contact forms, enquiry emails, booking requests, or website layouts. Testing might involve trying these yourself, getting feedback from customers, or reviewing them with accessibility in mind.

Having channels available is different from having channels that work well for everyone.
Response Options: Yes - we've tested them and are confident they work well | We've tested some channels, but not all | We haven't formally tested them, but we haven't had issues raised | Not sure - we've never checked this | No - we haven't tested this yet

Question Text: Which contact channels have been tested for accessibility?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. This helps identify gaps and prioritise areas for review.

If testing hasn't happened, Access Compass can provide an indicative review of publicly accessible channels.
Response Options: Website contact forms | Booking or enquiry forms | Email responses and attachments | Mobile experience | Confirmation emails or follow-up communications | None / not sure
Condition: B1-D-5d != Yes - we've tested them and are confident they work well

Question Text: Would you like Access Compass to review your contact channels as part of this assessment?
Helper Text:
This review is indicative only and based on publicly available information. It helps identify potential barriers but does not replace a full technical audit.

We can assess things like whether forms have visible labels, whether required fields are clearly indicated, and whether obvious contrast or navigation issues exist.
Response Options: Yes - please review this for me | No - note this as an area to review later
Condition: B1-D-5d = Not sure OR No - we haven't tested this yet

Question Text: How is guidance for responding to accessibility enquiries managed?
Helper Text:
This explores whether staff have clear, consistent information to draw on when responding to questions.

Documented guidance helps ensure consistent, confident responses.
Response Options: Written down and accessible to staff | Shared informally between team members | Based on individual knowledge and experience | No guidance exists | Not sure

Question Text: What happens when the first staff member doesn't know the answer to an accessibility question?
Helper Text:
This explores escalation and follow-through. Good practice includes:

• A clear person or resource to consult
• Permission and encouragement to say 'I'll find out'
• A process for following up with the customer

Customers understand when staff need to check. What matters is that follow-through happens.
Response Options: Clear escalation path and follow-up process | Staff usually find someone who knows | Often left unresolved | Not sure

Question Text: Are staff encouraged to say 'I don't know
Helper Text: but I'll find out' when needed?
Response Options:
This reflects your service culture. Staff who feel safe acknowledging uncertainty are more likely to provide accurate information than those who feel pressured to answer immediately.

Encouraging honest responses builds trust with customers and improves information quality over time.
Condition: Yes - this is encouraged | Sometimes | No - staff feel they should always have an answer | Not sure

Question Text: What's the main barrier to offering familiarisation visits?
Helper Text:
Select all that apply. Understanding barriers helps identify practical solutions.

Even simple options like quiet arrival times or virtual tours can make a significant difference.
Response Options: Time or scheduling constraints | Staffing availability | Lack of awareness or established process | Unclear demand or customer interest | Liability or safety concerns | Other

Question Text: How are familiarisation visits communicated to customers?
Helper Text:
If you offer familiarisation visits, consider how customers would know this is available.

Is it mentioned on your website, in booking communications, or when customers enquire about accessibility? Is the process documented anywhere for staff reference?

Visibility matters. An excellent offer has limited value if customers don't know it exists.
Response Options: Mentioned on website | Included in booking communications | Offered when customers enquire | Staff know to offer when relevant | Not actively communicated | Other

Question Text: Is your transport information specific to accessibility needs?
Helper Text:
Generic directions are less useful than accessibility-specific guidance.

Transport information that stops at 'nearest bus stop' may not address real planning needs.
Response Options: Yes - specifically addresses accessibility | Partially - some accessibility detail | No - generic directions only | Not sure

Question Text: Does your transport information describe the 'last 50 metres' of the journey?
Helper Text:
The final approach to your venue is often where visits fail. This might include:

• Distance from drop-off or parking to entrance
• Surface conditions (gravel, slopes, uneven ground)
• Whether the path is under cover
• Any level changes or obstacles
• Where to go if the main entrance isn't accessible

This detail helps customers complete their journey confidently.
Response Options: Yes - includes detailed approach information | Partially - some detail | No - not covered | Not sure

Question Text: Is your accessibility information consistent across all platforms?
Helper Text:
Inconsistent information creates confusion and erodes trust.

Check whether information matches across:
• Your website
• Booking platforms
• Google Business Profile and third-party listings
• Printed materials and signage

Discrepancies often occur when information is updated in one place but not others.
Response Options: Yes - consistent everywhere | Mostly consistent | No - known inconsistencies | Not sure - haven't checked

Question Text: Do you clearly state limitations or barriers that still exist?
Helper Text:
Negative disclosure builds trust and helps customers make informed decisions.

Honest statements like 'Our upper floor is not accessible by lift' or 'Background noise can be high during peak times' are more useful than silence.

Customers would rather know about limitations in advance than discover them on arrival.
Response Options: Yes - we clearly state known limitations | Partially - some limitations mentioned | No - we only highlight positives | Not sure

Question Text: Do you invite feedback about the accuracy of your accessibility information?
Helper Text:
Customers often notice things that internal reviews miss.

This creates a feedback loop that keeps information accurate over time.
Response Options: Yes - we actively invite feedback | We accept feedback but don't actively invite it | No | Not sure

Question Text: Who is responsible for maintaining your accessibility information?
Helper Text:
Clear ownership helps ensure information stays current.

When no one is responsible, information often becomes outdated without anyone noticing.
Response Options: A named role or individual | Shared across multiple people | No clear owner | Not sure

Question Text: Can all website content be accessed using only a keyboard (no mouse required)?
Helper Text: Try navigating your site using only Tab, Enter, and arrow keys.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do all images on your website have alt text or image descriptions?
Helper Text:
Alt text and image descriptions both help people understand images, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Alt text is a short description added directly to an image. It is read automatically by screen readers and should briefly explain the purpose of the image in context.

Image descriptions are longer explanations provided in nearby text or linked content. They are useful for complex images such as charts, diagrams, maps, or detailed visuals that need more explanation than a short alt text allows.
Response Options: Yes | Some images | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is your website text easy to read with good contrast between text and background?
Helper Text:
Good colour contrast makes text easier to read. Text should clearly stand out from the background, for example dark text on a light background, or light text on a dark background. Text that blends into the background, uses very light colours, or sits on busy images can be hard to read.

If you need to strain your eyes, zoom in, or adjust your screen to read the text comfortably, or if you cannot easily scan the page, the contrast may not be strong enough.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Can users resize text up to 400% without losing content or functionality?
Helper Text:
Text resizing allows users to increase the size of text without breaking the page. When text is increased, content should remain visible and usable. Text should not overlap, disappear, be cut off, or require sideways scrolling to read. Buttons, menus, and forms should still work as expected.

You can usually test this by zooming your browser or increasing text size and checking whether the page still works smoothly.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Does your website work well on mobile devices?
Helper Text:
A website that works well on mobile is easy to use on a phone or tablet, not just on a desktop computer.

On mobile devices, text should be readable without zooming, buttons and links should be easy to tap, and content should fit the screen without needing to scroll sideways. Menus, forms, and key features should still work smoothly.

You can check this by opening your website on a phone and trying to complete common tasks, such as finding information, using the menu, or submitting a form.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Enter your website URL for accessibility analysis
Helper Text: We can perform an automated accessibility audit of your website using industry-standard tools (WAVE integration coming soon). This checks for WCAG 2.1 compliance including contrast, structure, labels, and more.
Response Options: Free text (URL)

Question Text: Can customers share their accessibility requirements when booking online?
Helper Text:
This refers to whether customers have a clear way to tell you about their accessibility needs during the online booking process.

This might include a dedicated accessibility question, a free-text field, a tick box, or a notes section where customers can share requirements such as mobility access, hearing or vision support, sensory considerations, or assistance needs.

It should be easy to find, optional to complete, and reviewed by staff so requests can be acknowledged and responded to.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | We don't have online booking | Not sure

Question Text: Are error messages on forms clear and helpful?
Helper Text: Good error messages explain what went wrong and how to fix it.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do your videos have captions or subtitles?
Helper Text:
Captions or subtitles display spoken words and important sounds from a video as text on the screen. Captions are especially important for videos that share information, instructions, or stories.

Captions should be accurate, easy to read, and available for all spoken content, not just key moments.
Response Options: Yes - all videos | Some videos | No | We don't use video | Not sure

Question Text: Do you include alt text and image descriptions when posting on social media?
Helper Text:
Alt text and image descriptions both help people understand images, but they are used in slightly different ways.

Alt text is a short description added directly to an image. It is read automatically by screen readers and should briefly explain the purpose of the image in context.

Image descriptions are longer explanations provided in nearby text or linked content. They are useful for complex images such as charts, diagrams, maps, or detailed visuals that need more explanation than a short alt text allows.
Response Options: Yes - always | Sometimes | No | We don't use social media | Not sure

Question Text: Are video controls accessible (play, pause, volume)?
Helper Text:
Accessible video controls allow users to easily play, pause, stop, and adjust the volume of a video.

If a video plays automatically, users should be able to quickly pause or stop it. Controls should be easy to find, clearly labelled, and usable with a keyboard, mouse, or touch.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | We don't use video | Not sure

Question Text: Upload a screenshot of a social media post for accessibility analysis
Helper Text: Our AI will analyze your social media posts for accessibility features like alt text presence, caption readability, contrast, and inclusive language.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Enter a social media profile URL for accessibility review
Helper Text: We can review your social media presence for accessibility practices including alt text usage, caption quality, and content accessibility.
Response Options: Free text (URL)

Question Text: Do you have designated accessible parking spaces?
Helper Text: Designated accessible parking spaces are parking bays set aside for people with disability and mobility needs. These spaces are typically wider than standard bays and clearly identified with signage and ground markings so they are easy to recognise.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable (no parking)

Question Text: Are accessible parking spaces located close to the main entrance?
Helper Text: Accessible parking should be positioned as close as reasonably possible to the main entrance to reduce the distance people need to travel.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is there a drop-off zone near the entrance for customers who need it?
Helper Text: A drop-off zone allows customers to be safely set down close to the entrance without needing to park. This area should be step free and connected to the entrance by a clear, accessible path.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is the path from accessible parking to the entrance smooth and level?
Helper Text: The path from parking to the entrance should be easy to move along without steps, sudden level changes, loose surfaces, or obstacles.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is the path wide enough for people using mobility aids, walking with companions or using service animals (at least 1 metre)?
Helper Text: Paths should be wide enough for wheelchair users, people with walking aids, service animals, or those walking side by side. A minimum clear width of around 1 metre helps people move comfortably without needing to step aside or navigate obstacles.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Would a first-time visitor know where to find accessible parking?
Helper Text: Accessible parking should be easy to locate without prior knowledge of the site. Clear signage, logical placement, and visible pathways help first-time visitors feel confident and reduce the need to ask for assistance.
Response Options: Yes | Probably | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do staff know how to direct customers to accessible parking and entry points?
Helper Text: Staff should be able to confidently explain where accessible parking, drop-off zones, and step-free entrances are located. This reduces stress for customers and avoids the need for them to navigate the site on their own.
Response Options: Yes | Some staff | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is the parking area well-lit for customers arriving in low light?
Helper Text: Good lighting helps customers feel safe and confident when arriving early in the morning, evening, or at night. Well-lit parking areas help everyone navigate paths, signage, and entrances more easily.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: During busy periods, are accessible parking spaces still available and not blocked?
Helper Text: This looks at what happens when your site is at its busiest. Accessible parking spaces should remain usable and not be blocked by other vehicles, deliveries, temporary signage, or bins, even during peak periods or events.
Response Options: Yes - always protected | Usually | Sometimes blocked | Not sure

Question Text: Is the path from parking protected from weather (covered or sheltered)?
Helper Text: A protected or sheltered path helps people move from parking to the entrance more comfortably in rain, heat, or strong sun.
Response Options: Yes - fully covered | Partially covered | No | Not applicable

Question Text: Are there rest points or seating along longer paths from parking?
Helper Text: Rest points or seating give people a chance to pause and recover if they need to walk longer distances from parking to the entrance.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable (short distance)

Question Text: Is the surface of accessible parking spaces firm and slip-resistant?
Helper Text: Accessible parking surfaces should be stable and easy to move across. Loose gravel, uneven paving, or slippery surfaces can make it difficult or unsafe for people using the space.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are accessible parking spaces clearly marked with both ground markings and vertical signage?
Helper Text: Take a photo of the accessible parking signage.
Response Options: Yes - both | Ground markings only | Vertical signage only | Neither | Not sure

Question Text: Do you have a policy for managing misuse of accessible parking spaces?
Helper Text: This refers to whether your organisation has a clear approach for discouraging or responding to non-eligible use of accessible parking. A simple policy helps protect access for customers who rely on these spaces and supports staff to respond consistently and respectfully.
Response Options: Yes | Informal approach | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is information about accessible parking included on your website?
Helper Text: Providing accessible parking information online helps customers plan their visit in advance. This might include the location of the nearest accessible spaces (even if you don't have one on-site), drop-off areas, or any relevant access considerations.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: In low light conditions, is the path clearly visible and safely navigable?
Helper Text: Paths should remain easy to see and follow in early mornings, evenings, or poor weather. Clear lighting, visible edges, and unobstructed paths help reduce trip risks.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is your main entrance step-free?
Helper Text:
A step-free entrance allows customers to enter the building without needing to step up or down.

This means there are no stairs, raised thresholds, changes in height between surfaces or sudden level changes at the main entrance.

If a ramp is used, it should be clearly connected to the main entrance and easy to identify.
Response Options: Yes | No

Question Text: Is the main entrance door at least 850mm wide?
Helper Text: A clear opening of at least 850mm is a common benchmark for allowing safe and independent access. Measure the doorway at its narrowest point when the door is fully open.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are entrance doors easy to open (automatic, light push, or lever handles)?
Helper Text: Entrance doors should be easy to use without requiring significant strength or complex movements. Automatic doors, doors with a light push force, or doors with lever or D handles are easier for people to use independently.
Response Options: Yes - automatic | Yes - easy to open manually | No - heavy or difficult | Not sure

Question Text: Is the main entrance clearly visible and identifiable from the street or parking area?
Helper Text: Visitors should be able to easily see and recognise the main entrance as they approach the building. Clear sightlines, lighting, signage, and visual cues help reduce confusion and improve confidence, especially for first-time visitors.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: If there is an alternative accessible entrance, is it clearly signed?
Helper Text: If the main entrance is not accessible, any alternative accessible entrance should be clearly signposted from the main approach. Signage should guide customers without requiring them to ask for assistance or search the site.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not applicable (main entrance is accessible)

Question Text: Do staff know how to assist customers who need support entering the building?
Helper Text: Staff should be aware of how to support customers who may need assistance at the entrance, such as opening doors, explaining where to enter, or guiding people to an accessible entry point. Support should be offered respectfully and only when needed.
Response Options: Yes | Some staff | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is there adequate lighting at the entrance for customers with low vision?
Helper Text: Good lighting at the entrance helps people identify doors, handles, signage, and level changes. This is especially important in low light conditions, at night, or during poor weather.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are there tactile ground surface indicators at key entry points?
Helper Text:
Tactile ground surface indicators are textured ground surfaces, often made up of raised dots or bars, installed on the ground at key locations. They can be felt underfoot or with a cane.

They help people who are blind or have low vision identify important points such as entrances, hazards, or changes in direction, and provide clear wayfinding and safety information at entry points.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: If there is a ramp, does it have compliant handrails on both sides?
Helper Text: Handrails on both sides of a ramp help users feel safer when moving up or down the ramp and allow people to choose the side that suits them best.
Response Options: Yes | One side only | No | Not applicable (no ramp)

Question Text: What is the clear opening width of the main entrance door?
Helper Text: This refers to the usable width of the doorway when the door is fully open, measured at the narrowest point. The clear opening determines whether wheelchair users and people with mobility aids can enter independently.
Response Options: Free text (measurement)

Question Text: Is the door handle at an accessible height (900-1100mm from floor)?
Helper Text: Door handles positioned within this height range are easier to reach for wheelchair users, people of short stature, and those with limited arm movement. Handles outside this range can be difficult or impossible for some people to use.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not sure | Not applicable (automatic doors)

Question Text: Is there a level landing area at the entrance (at least 1500mm x 1500mm)?
Helper Text: A level landing provides space for people to stop, turn, or steady themselves before opening the door. This is especially important for wheelchair users, people using walking aids, or anyone who needs extra time to manage doors.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is the door threshold level? (The maximum height is 13mm)
Helper Text: Low thresholds reduce the effort needed to move into the building and lower the risk of wheels catching or people tripping. High or uneven thresholds can be a barrier for wheelchair users and people with mobility or balance challenges.
Response Options: Yes (13mm or less) | No (higher than 13mm) | Not sure

Question Text: Are glass doors marked with contrasting strips or patterns?
Helper Text: Clear glass doors can be difficult to see. Contrasting strips or patterns help people identify the door and avoid walking into it, supporting people with low vision as well as all visitors.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable (no glass doors)

Question Text: During busy periods, does the entrance become congested or blocked?
Helper Text: This considers how the entrance functions at peak times. Congestion from queues, furniture, displays, service counters or security checks can make it difficult for people to enter safely.
Response Options: No - stays clear | Sometimes | Yes - often congested | Not sure

Question Text: If there is an intercom or bell, is it located at an accessible height between 900 and 1100mm from the floor?
Helper Text: An accessible intercom or bell allows customers to request entry or assistance independently, without needing to reach too high or stretch. It should be easy to see, reach, and use from a seated or standing position.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable

Question Text: If automatic doors are used, do they stay open long enough for slow-moving visitors?
Helper Text: Automatic doors should allow enough time for people who move more slowly to pass through safely. Doors that close too quickly can cause stress or increase the risk of injury.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable | Not sure

Question Text: Is there a mat or surface change at the entrance that could cause a trip hazard?
Helper Text: Mats or surface changes should lie flat and be securely fixed. Loose edges, thick mats, or sudden changes in surface level can create trip hazards for people with low vision, balance issues, or mobility aids.
Response Options: No hazard present | Potential hazard | Not sure

Question Text: Upload a photo of your entrance for accessibility analysis
Helper Text: Our AI will analyze your entrance against AS 1428.1 and Access to Premises Standards for door width, threshold, visibility, and step-free access.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Upload a photo of your entrance door for analysis
Helper Text: We can analyze door width, handle type, threshold height, and visual contrast against accessibility standards.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Upload a photo of any ramp at your entrance
Helper Text: We can analyze ramp gradient, width, handrails, and landing areas against AS 1428.1 requirements.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Are main circulation paths at least 1 metre wide?
Helper Text: Main circulation paths are the primary walkways people use to move through your space. A clear width of at least 1 metre helps wheelchair users, people using mobility aids, those walking with companions, or using service animals to move comfortably.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are paths kept clear of obstacles and trip hazards?
Helper Text: Circulation paths should be free from obstacles such as furniture, displays, cords, mats, bins, or clutter. Clear paths reduce trip risks and make it easier for people to move safely and confidently through the space.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: If there are level changes, is there an accessible alternative (lift, ramp)?
Helper Text: Where there are steps or changes in level, there should be an accessible alternative such as a ramp or lift so all customers can reach the same areas.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not applicable (single level)

Question Text: Would a customer using a mobility aid be able to navigate your space independently?
Helper Text: This considers the overall experience of moving through your space without assistance. Clear paths, adequate width, smooth surfaces, and accessible alternatives help customers navigate confidently and independently.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | With difficulty | No | Not sure

Question Text: Upload a photo of your pathways for accessibility analysis
Helper Text: Our AI will analyze your pathways for width, surface condition, obstacles, and trip hazards based on AS 1428.1 standards.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Upload a photo of your ground surfaces for analysis
Helper Text: We can analyze floor surfaces for slip resistance, level changes, and accessibility compliance.
Response Options: File upload

Question Text: Is there seating available in queue areas for people who cannot stand for long?
Helper Text: Seating in queue areas allows people with fatigue, chronic pain, mobility conditions, or health needs to rest while waiting. Even a small number of seats can make waiting more manageable and inclusive.
Response Options: Yes | Limited | No | Not applicable (no queues)

Question Text: Can customers request priority access when needed?
Helper Text: Priority access gives customers a way to avoid long waits when standing is difficult. This might include staff-managed entry, priority ordering, alternative waiting arrangements, or clear processes for requesting assistance.
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do staff know how to accommodate customers who need queue assistance?
Helper Text: Staff should understand how to respond respectfully and confidently when a customer needs support with queuing. This includes offering alternatives without requiring customers to explain or justify their needs.
Response Options: Yes | Some staff | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is there a variety of seating options (with arms, without arms, different heights)?
Helper Text: Different seating types support different bodies and needs. Seats with arms can help people stand up, while varied heights and armless options support comfort and choice.
Response Options: Yes | Limited variety | No | Not applicable

Question Text: Is there space for wheelchair users alongside seated companions?
Helper Text: Seating areas should include space where wheelchair users can sit next to friends, family, or companions rather than being separated from the group.
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are tables and counters at accessible heights for wheelchair users?
Helper Text: Accessible tables and counters allow wheelchair users to approach, sit, and use the surface comfortably. As a guide, an accessible table or counter is usually between 750 and 850mm high, with clear knee space underneath of at least 700mm high and 800mm wide. At least one accessible option should be available where customers interact, dine, or make transactions.
Response Options: Yes | Some | No | Not sure

Question Text: Can furniture be rearranged to accommodate different needs?
Helper Text: Flexible furniture allows spaces to adapt to different access needs. The ability to move chairs or tables can help create space for wheelchairs, prams, or service animals when required.
Response Options: Yes | Some furniture | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you have at least one accessible toilet?
Helper Text: An accessible toilet provides essential facilities for people with disability, mobility needs, or who require assistance. Having at least one accessible toilet supports longer and more comfortable visits.
Response Options: Yes | No

Question Text: Do you know where the nearest accessible toilet is?
Helper Text: Staff should be able to confidently direct customers to the nearest accessible toilet, including providing clear directions or signage information. This helps customers avoid unnecessary searching or discomfort, especially in larger or shared spaces.
Response Options: Yes | Not sure

Question Text: Is the accessible toilet clearly signed and easy to find?
Helper Text: Clear signage helps customers locate the accessible toilet without needing to ask for assistance. Signage should be visible from key areas within the space.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is the accessible toilet kept clear of storage and obstacles?
Helper Text: Accessible toilets should not be used for storage. Clear floor space and unobstructed fittings are necessary for safe and independent use.
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes used for storage | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is there an emergency alarm in the accessible toilet?
Helper Text: An emergency alarm allows users to call for assistance if needed. It should be clearly visible, reachable from the toilet and floor, and known to staff.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is lighting adequate for reading and navigation?
Helper Text:
Adequate lighting helps people read signs, see hazards, and move around safely. Poor lighting can make navigation difficult for people with low vision and increase trip risks for everyone.

As a general guide, indoor circulation areas are often around 100–200 lux, while areas used for reading, forms, or detailed tasks are closer to 300–500 lux. Lighting levels can be roughly checked using a free light (lux) meter app on a smartphone. Lighting should be even, without strong glare or deep shadows.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are there quiet or reset spaces available for people who need a break from noise?
Helper Text:
Quiet or reset spaces provide a calm area where people can step away from noise, crowds, or sensory input. These spaces support people with sensory sensitivities, anxiety, neurodivergence, fatigue, or health conditions.

A quiet space does not need to be large or formal, but it should be clearly identified, reasonably quiet, and free from interruptions where possible.
Response Options: Yes | Informal options | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is background noise at a level that allows conversation?
Helper Text: Background noise should allow people to speak and be heard without raising their voice. Consider whether music, machinery, crowds, or echoes make it hard to communicate, especially at service counters or seating areas.
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are there any flashing lights or sudden loud noises that could affect some visitors?
Helper Text:
Flashing lights, strobe effects, alarms, or sudden loud noises can be distressing or disorienting for some people, including those with sensory sensitivities, migraines, epilepsy, or anxiety.

Where these elements are used, consider whether warnings are provided and whether quieter or calmer alternatives are available.
Response Options: No | Yes - with warnings | Yes - without warnings | Not sure

Question Text: Is the indoor temperature comfortable and able to be adjusted or managed for different needs?
Helper Text:
Comfortable and stable indoor temperatures help people stay focused, safe, and well. Extreme heat or cold can affect people with health conditions, fatigue, sensory sensitivities, or those taking certain medications.

Where possible, there should be ways to manage temperature, such as air conditioning, heating, fans, or shaded areas. Staff awareness of temperature issues and the ability to respond to concerns can also support comfort.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are sensory kits or supports available for customers and visitors?
Helper Text:
Sensory kits typically include items like noise-cancelling headphones or ear plugs, fidget tools, sunglasses, communication cards, or weighted lap pads. These supports help people with sensory sensitivities, autism, anxiety, or other conditions manage their environment and feel more comfortable during their visit.

Kits do not need to be elaborate—even a small selection of items available on request can make a significant difference.
Response Options: Yes | Limited selection | No | Considering it

Question Text: Do you offer relaxed or sensory-friendly sessions?
Helper Text:
Relaxed or sensory-friendly sessions are modified experiences with reduced sensory input. This might include lower lighting, reduced sound levels, fewer crowds, quieter music or no music, and a more flexible atmosphere.

These sessions support people with autism, sensory processing differences, anxiety, dementia, or anyone who benefits from a calmer environment. They are commonly offered by cinemas, museums, theatres, and retail venues.
Response Options: Yes - regularly | Yes - occasionally | No | Considering it | Not applicable

Question Text: Do you offer assisted listening devices or hearing augmentation?
Helper Text:
Assisted listening devices help people who are deaf or hard of hearing to hear more clearly. These include:

• Hearing loops (induction loops) – transmit sound directly to hearing aids with T-coil
• FM systems – use radio signals to transmit sound to a receiver
• Infrared systems – use light to transmit sound
• Personal amplifiers – portable devices that amplify sound

Note: Under the Access to Premises Standard, venues with inbuilt amplification systems (such as PA systems or performance venues) are required to provide hearing augmentation.
Response Options: Yes | No | Not applicable | Not sure

Response Options: File upload

Helper Text:
This might include wheelchairs for loan, sensory kits, communication cards, magnifiers, portable seating, or hearing loop receivers.

Even a small selection of equipment can make a significant difference to some visitors.
Response Options: Yes - multiple items available | Yes - limited selection | No - but considering it | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do customers know what equipment is available before they visit?
Helper Text:
Customers need to know what's available in order to plan. If equipment exists but isn't communicated, it may not be used.

This information might appear on your website, in booking confirmations, or in pre-visit information.

Items can be provided in kits or individually. Even a small selection can make a significant difference.

Equipment should be in good working condition, clean, and safe to use.

Staff should be able to quickly identify what equipment is available, know where equipment is stored, understand how to offer it respectfully, and provide basic guidance on use if needed.

Confident staff help customers access equipment without unnecessary delay or awkwardness.

Question Text: Is signage clear, with good contrast and readable font sizes?
Helper Text: Clear signage uses high contrast between text and background, simple fonts, title case, and text sizes that can be read at a distance. Signs should avoid overly decorative fonts, low contrast colours, or cluttered layouts.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are signs placed at consistent heights and locations?
Helper Text:
Consistent placement helps people know where to look for information. As a general guide, wall-mounted signs are often placed so the main information is between around 1200 and 1600mm from the floor, making them visible to people who are standing or seated.

Signs should be positioned where people naturally pause or make decisions, such as entrances, intersections, and key facilities.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are accessible facilities (toilets, lifts) clearly signed?
Helper Text: Accessible facilities should be clearly identified using recognisable symbols and plain language. Clear signage helps people find essential facilities without needing to ask for assistance or search the space.

Question Text: Would a first-time visitor be able to navigate independently?
Helper Text:
This question considers the overall experience of navigating your space for someone who has never visited before. Clear signage, logical layout, good lighting, manageable noise levels, and visible landmarks all support independent navigation.

If someone unfamiliar with the space can find their way without assistance, the environment is likely working well.
Response Options: Yes | Mostly | With difficulty | No | Not sure

Question Text: Are large print versions of key materials available?
Helper Text: Large print materials support people with low vision or who find standard text difficult to read. As a general guide, large print uses a minimum of 16–18 point font, clear sans serif typefaces, strong contrast, and simple layouts. Key materials might include menus, programs, safety instructions, guides, or forms.
Response Options: Yes | Some materials | No | Not sure

Question Text: Can staff read menus or materials aloud for customers who need it?
Helper Text: Some customers may prefer or require information to be read aloud. Staff should feel comfortable offering this support respectfully and without drawing attention to the customer.

Question Text: Are digital alternatives available (QR codes, online menus)?
Helper Text: Digital alternatives allow customers to access information on their own devices using screen readers, zoom, or other accessibility settings. QR codes or online versions should link to accessible content that is easy to navigate and read.
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you offer key information in alternative formats such as Easy Read or Plain English?
Helper Text:
Alternative formats help people with different reading abilities, cognitive disabilities, or those who speak English as a second language.

**Easy Read** uses simple words, short sentences, and images to explain information. It is designed for people with intellectual disability or learning difficulties.

**Plain English** uses clear, straightforward language that avoids jargon, technical terms, and complex sentences. It makes information accessible to a wider audience.

Key information might include safety instructions, service descriptions, or booking information.
Response Options: Yes | Some materials | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you provide disability inclusion training to support an inclusive workplace culture?

This might include training on:

• The social model of disability

This training helps staff see accessibility as a core value rather than a task to complete.

Question Text: Is there a quiet space available for customers who become overwhelmed?
Helper Text: A quiet or low-stimulation space allows customers to step away from noise or crowds if they feel overwhelmed. This supports people with sensory sensitivities, anxiety, or fatigue.

• Partnering with disability employment organisations
• Attending disability-focused career fairs
Response Options: Yes | Sometimes | No | Not sure

Question Text: Is your recruitment process accessible to people with disability?
Helper Text:
An accessible recruitment process ensures all candidates can apply and participate equally. Consider:

• Job ads in accessible formats
• Application forms that work with screen readers
• Interview locations that are physically accessible
• Offering adjustments during interviews
• Clear information about accessibility support available
Response Options: Yes | Partially | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you provide workplace adjustments for employees with disability?
Helper Text:
Workplace adjustments (reasonable adjustments) are changes to the work environment, schedule, or role that enable employees with disability to perform their job effectively. Examples include:

• Modified workstations or equipment
• Flexible working hours or locations
• Assistive technology (screen readers, voice recognition)
• Modified duties or job restructuring
• Support workers or job coaches
• Additional breaks or quiet spaces
Response Options: Yes | Case by case | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you have a process for employees to request workplace adjustments?
Helper Text:
A clear process helps employees feel comfortable requesting support. Best practice includes:

• Information about available adjustments
• Clear point of contact for requests
• Confidential discussion process
• Reasonable timeframes for implementation
• Regular review of adjustments
Response Options: Yes | Informal process | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do you track the employment of people with disability in your organisation?
Helper Text:
Tracking employment data (with appropriate consent and privacy protections) helps you understand your workforce diversity and set improvement goals. This might include:

• Voluntary disclosure surveys
• Tracking adjustment requests
• Monitoring retention rates
• Setting employment targets
Response Options: Yes | Informally | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do managers receive training on supporting employees with disability?
Helper Text:
Manager training helps create a supportive environment. Training might cover:

• Understanding disability and inclusion
• Having conversations about adjustments
• Legal obligations and rights
• Creating inclusive team environments
• Supporting career development
Response Options: Yes | Some managers | No | Not sure

Question Text: Do all customer-facing staff receive disability awareness training?
Helper Text:
Disability awareness training helps staff interact confidently and respectfully with customers with disability. Good training covers:

• Understanding different types of disability

• Offering assistance appropriately
• Using accessible facilities and equipment
• Responding to specific requests
